meta.dc:rights: The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

main.longTitle: An Ordinance to provide for the regulation of private healthcare facilities; to repeal the Hospitals, Nursing Homes and Maternity Homes Registration Ordinance and provide for the transfer of nursing homes for elderly persons to be regulated under the Residential Care Homes (Elderly Persons) Ordinance; to repeal the Medical Clinics Ordinance and its subsidiary legislation; and to provide for incidental and related matters.

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Private Healthcare Facilities Ordinance.
This Ordinance comes into operation on a day to be appointed by the Secretary for Health by notice published in the Gazette. (Amended L.N. 144 of 2022)

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance—
subsection.def: authorized officer (獲授權人員) means a public officer authorized by the Director under section 98;
body corporate (法人團體) does not include—(a)a corporation incorporated outside Hong Kong; or(b)a corporation sole;
case panel (個案小組) means a panel appointed under section 78;
chief medical executive (醫務行政總監) means a person appointed under section 49;
clinic (診所)—see section 6;
code of practice (實務守則) means a code of practice issued under section 102;
company (公司) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622);
Complaints Committee (投訴委員會) means the Committee on Complaints against Private Healthcare Facilities established under section 71;
day procedure centre (日間醫療中心)—see section 5;
dental practice (牙科執業) means the professional practice of a registered dentist;
direction (指示) means a direction given under section 104;
Director (署長) means the Director of Health;
exempted clinic (豁免診所) means a small practice clinic for which an exemption under section 43 is in force;
facility complaint (對機構投訴) means a complaint made under section 82;
function (職能) includes a power and a duty;
health services establishment (衞生服務機構)—see section 7;
healthcare professional (醫護專業人員) means a person specified in Schedule 7;
hospital (醫院)—see section 4;
medical practice (醫科執業) means the professional practice of a registered medical practitioner;

medical service (醫療服務), in relation to a patient, means a medical diagnosis, treatment (other than first aid treatment) or care for the patient given by—(a)a registered medical practitioner; or(b)a registered dentist;
minor medical procedure (小型醫療程序) means a medical procedure—(a)that is not a scheduled medical procedure; and(b)that is carried out in an ambulatory setting;

operator (營辦人) means—(a)in relation to a private healthcare facility for which a licence is in force—the licensee of the facility; or(b)in relation to an exempted clinic—(i)if the clinic is operated by an individual as a sole proprietor—the individual;(ii)if the clinic is operated by a partnership—each partner of the partnership; or(iii)if the clinic is operated by a company—each director of the company;
outreach facility (外展設施) means premises that are not normally used for medical purposes but are temporarily or occasionally used for providing outreach medical services;
outreach medical services (外展醫療服務)—see section 9;
permitted facility (獲准機構) means—(a)a private healthcare facility for which a licence is in force; or(b)an exempted clinic;
practice (執業)—see subsection (2);
preliminary processing panel (初步處理小組) means a panel appointed under section 77;

premises (處所) includes any place and, in particular, includes the following—(a)any land or building;(b)any vehicle or vessel (other than a sea-going ship as defined in the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) Ordinance (Cap. 478));(c)any part of any land or building or of any vehicle or vessel mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b);Note— See also section 8.
private healthcare facility (私營醫療機構)—see section 3;
provisional licence (暫准牌照) means a licence of a provisional nature issued under section 135 or 136;
registered medical practitioner (註冊醫生) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161);
regulations (規例) means regulations made under section 122;
scheduled clinic (附表診所) means a clinic listed in Schedule 6;
scheduled nursing home (附表護養院) has the meaning given by section 124;
scheduled university (附表大學) means a university specified in Schedule 1;
Secretary (局長) means the Secretary for Health; (Amended L.N. 144 of 2022)
small practice clinic (小型執業診所)—see section 41;
society (社團) means a society, or a branch of a society, registered under section 5A(1), or exempted from registration under section 5A(2), of the Societies Ordinance (Cap. 151);
substitute decision maker (代決人)—see section 8A. (Added 21 of 2024 s. 40)

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance, a reference to a practice is a reference to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a dental practice; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a medical practice.

subsection.content: In this Ordinance, a reference to a class of specialized service is a reference to the medical procedures described in column 2 of Schedule 3 corresponding to the class listed in column 1 of that Schedule.
In this Ordinance, a reference to a person serving a clinic is a reference to the person providing a medical service to a patient at the clinic.

subsection.leadIn: A private healthcare facility is any of the following facilities that is not managed or controlled by a specified authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a hospital;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a day procedure centre;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a clinic;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a health services establishment,

subsection.continued: other than a day procedure centre, clinic or health services establishment primarily used for teaching or research relating to medicine or dentistry and that is managed or controlled by a scheduled university.

subsection.content: Also, a private healthcare facility does not include any premises that are not normally used for medical purposes but are temporarily used for emergency or rescue purposes.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Meaning of hospital
section.leadIn: A hospital is any premises that are used, or intended to be used, for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: providing medical services to patients, with lodging;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: carrying out medical procedures on patients, with lodging; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: receiving—

subparagraph.content: a pregnant woman for childbirth; or
a woman immediately after she gives birth to a child,

section.continued: but does not include the premises specified in Schedule 2.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Meaning of day procedure centre
section.leadIn: A day procedure centre is any premises—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that do not form part of the premises of a hospital; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that are used, or intended to be used, for carrying out scheduled medical procedures on patients, without lodging, whether or not the premises are also used, or intended to be used, for—

subparagraph.content: providing medical services to patients, without lodging; or
carrying out minor medical procedures on patients, without lodging.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Meaning of clinic
section.leadIn: A clinic is any premises—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that do not form part of the premises of a hospital, a day procedure centre or an outreach facility; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that are used, or intended to be used, for—

subparagraph.content: providing medical services to patients, without lodging; or
carrying out minor medical procedures on patients, without lodging.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Meaning of health services establishment
section.leadIn: A health services establishment is any premises—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that fall within a category specified in Schedule 9;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that do not form part of the premises of a hospital, a day procedure centre or a clinic; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: that are used, or intended to be used, in relation to—

subparagraph.content: assessing, maintaining or improving the health of patients; or
diagnosing or treating illnesses or disabilities, or suspected illnesses or disabilities, of patients.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Interpretation of premises in relation to private healthcare facility
section.leadIn: Premises, in relation to a private healthcare facility, comprise the places—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that are—

subparagraph.content: physically connected by internal access among themselves; or
physically attached or in close proximity to, or adjoining, one another; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that form a distinct whole for the facility to function as a single entity.

subsection.content: A person is a substitute decision maker of a patient if the person is an eligible person under subsection (2) or (3).

subsection.leadIn: For a patient who is aged below 16, the following are eligible persons for the purposes of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a person appointed by the court to manage the affairs of the patient;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: in the absence of the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a), (b) and (c)—the prescribed medical service provider that provides, or is about to provide, a medical service to the patient.

subsection.leadIn: For a patient who is aged 16 or above and who is of any of the following descriptions, the persons specified in subsection (4) are eligible persons for the purposes of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being mentally incapacitated as defined by section 2(1) of the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136) (Cap. 136);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: being incapable of managing his or her own affairs.

subsection.leadIn: The following are persons specified for the purposes of subsection (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person appointed under Cap. 136 to be the guardian of the patient;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: if the guardianship of the patient is vested in the Director of Social Welfare under section 44B(2A) or 59T(1) of Cap. 136—the Director of Social Welfare;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the functions of guardian of the patient are to be performed by the Director of Social Welfare or any other person under section 44B(2B) or 59T(2) of Cap. 136—the Director of Social Welfare or that other person;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a person appointed by the court to manage the affairs of the patient;

paragraph.name: f
g
paragraph.content: in the absence of the persons mentioned in paragraphs (a), (b), (c), (d), (e) and (f)—the prescribed medical service provider that provides, or is about to provide, a medical service to the patient.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: PrescribedMedicalServiceProvider
def.leadIn: prescribed medical service provider (訂明醫療服務提供者) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Department of Health;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Hospital Authority; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the operator of a permitted facility.

subsection.leadIn: An outreach medical service is a medical service—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that is given—

subparagraph.content: as part of healthcare services provided in a temporary setting by the Government or the Hospital Authority;

as part of healthcare services provided in a temporary setting by a person registered as a medical practitioner with limited or temporary registration under the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161);
in a temporary setting for providing vaccination for disease prevention;
in a temporary setting for providing medical services to an individual taking part in, or attending, a sport event;
as part of healthcare services provided in premises specified in Schedule 5;
as part of a medical escort for patient transfer; or
to a patient in the patient’s home or place of accommodation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that does not, except in an emergency, involve—

subparagraph.content: a medical procedure that requires a form of sedation or anaesthesia (other than local anaesthesia); or
a scheduled medical procedure.

subsection.leadIn: Also, an outreach medical service is a medical service that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is given in a temporary setting for providing physical examination and medical consultation for health promotion; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: does not involve any medical procedure.

subsection.content: Also, an outreach medical service is a medical service that is given in a temporary setting as part of healthcare services provided without charge for charitable purposes as approved by the Director.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Prohibition on operating facility without licence

subsection.content: A person must not operate a private healthcare facility without a licence.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a person who operates a small practice clinic without a licence if an exemption given under section 43 for the clinic is in force.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the facility is a hospital—on conviction on indictment to a fine of $5,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the facility is not a hospital—on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

tr.td: This subsection came into operation on the following dates—

paragraph.content: 1 January 2021 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019;
30 June 2022 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 159 of 2021.

tr.td: Not yet in operation.

subsection.content: The licensee of a private healthcare facility must display the current certificate of licence for the facility in a conspicuous place in the facility.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the facility is a hospital—on summary conviction to a fine at level 6; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the facility is not a hospital—on summary conviction to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Prohibition on performing treatment or procedure causing personal injury

subsection.leadIn: A person who is not a healthcare professional must not on any premises (other than an excepted premises)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: purportedly perform a medical treatment or medical procedure for another person who is, or may be, suffering from a disease, injury or disability of mind or body; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cause personal injury to the other person during the treatment or procedure.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine of $200,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to imprisonment for 7 years.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: excepted premises (例外處所) means any of the following—(a)a permitted facility;(b)any premises specified in Schedule 2;(c)any premises exempted under section 128;(d)any premises managed or controlled by a specified authority;(e)a day procedure centre, clinic or health services establishment primarily used for teaching or research relating to medicine or dentistry and that is managed or controlled by a scheduled university;(f)any premises that are not normally used for medical purposes but are temporarily used for emergency or rescue purposes;

medical treatment (醫學治療), in relation to an individual, means a treatment (including any diagnosis and prescription for giving the treatment) of any description performed on the individual for treating of disease, injury or disability of mind or body other than the following—(a)dispensation of medicine or poison by a pharmacist registered under the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138);(b)dispensation of poison by a seller of poisons listed under the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138);(c)dispensation of Chinese herbal medicines under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549);(d)treatment given by a Chinese medicine practitioner registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549);(e)treatment given in the practice of a profession listed in Schedule 1 to the Allied Health Professions Ordinance (Cap. 359) by a person registered or licensed under that Ordinance to practise that profession; (Amended 33 of 2025 s. 210)(f)treatment given by a chiropractor registered under the Chiropractors Registration Ordinance (Cap. 428);(g)treatment given without payment by a family member or personal friend because of the family or personal relationship;(h)treatment given by way of first aid.

subsection.content: Subject to section 14, a person may apply to the Director for a licence to operate a private healthcare facility.

subsection.leadIn: The application must state which of the following types of private healthcare facility the licence is applied for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a hospital;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a day procedure centre;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a clinic;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a health services establishment.

subsection.leadIn: The application must also state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a hospital—the scale and scope of the services that are intended to be provided in the hospital;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for a day procedure centre—

subparagraph.content: the practice that is intended to be carried on in the centre;
the class of specialized service that is intended to be provided in the centre; and
the scale and scope of the services that are intended to be provided in the centre;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: for a clinic—

subparagraph.content: the practice that is intended to be carried on in the clinic;
the scale and scope of the services that are intended to be provided in the clinic; and
whether it is a scheduled clinic; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: for a health services establishment—

subparagraph.content: a category specified in Schedule 9 to which the establishment belongs; and
the scale and scope of the services that are intended to be provided in the establishment.

subsection.leadIn: For an application for a licence to be issued for a hospital—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant must be a company, or other body corporate, operated by a board of directors (however described); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the board of directors must include a person—

subparagraph.content: who is neither a registered medical practitioner nor a registered dentist; and
who is not an employee of the hospital.

subsection.leadIn: For an application for a licence to be issued for a clinic that is a scheduled clinic, the applicant must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who was registered under section 5(2) of the Medical Clinics Ordinance (Cap. 343) immediately before its repeal in respect of the scheduled clinic; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a registered medical practitioner—

subparagraph.content: who is currently practising in the scheduled clinic; and
whose name is not included in Part I of the General Register kept under section 6(1) of the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161) as at 1 April 2017.

subsection.leadIn: Any of the following persons that operates or has control over a private healthcare facility (other than a hospital or a clinic that is a scheduled clinic), or that intends to operate or have control over such a private healthcare facility, may apply for a licence for the facility—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an individual;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a partnership;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a company;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a body corporate other than a company;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a society.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Director’s decision on medical procedure is final
section.content: In processing an application made under section 13, the Director may decide whether a procedure is a medical procedure under column 2 or 3 of Schedule 3, and the Director’s decision is final for the purposes of the application.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Director may inspect premises and require amendment to application etc.
section.leadIn: Before deciding an application made under section 13, the Director may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after giving the applicant prior notice (either verbally or in writing), inspect the premises of the private healthcare facility to which the application relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: require the applicant to make any amendment to the application, or alteration or improvement to the premises, the Director considers necessary.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Issuing or refusing to issue licence

subsection.leadIn: On receiving an application made under section 13 in relation to a private healthcare facility, the Director may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issue a licence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse to issue a licence but only on a ground specified in section 18.

subsection.leadIn: When issuing a licence for the facility, the Director may specify the following in the licence, as appropriate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the practice that may be carried on in the facility;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the class of specialized service that may be provided in the facility;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the category of health services establishment to which the facility belongs;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the scale and scope of the services that may be provided in the facility.

subsection.content: A licence may be issued subject to the conditions that the Director considers appropriate.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Grounds for refusing to issue licence

subsection.leadIn: The following grounds are specified for the purpose of refusing to issue a licence under section 17(1)(b) for a private healthcare facility—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the applicant is a fit and proper person to operate or exercise control over the facility;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the person whom the applicant states is to be appointed as the chief medical executive for the facility is a fit and proper person to administer the facility;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the applicant has the ability to operate or exercise control over the facility in compliance with this Ordinance and the code of practice;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the premises (including the fittings and equipment in the premises) forming the facility are suitable to be used as the type of facility under application;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the applicant has suitable arrangements in place regarding the management and staffing of the facility;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the applicant has suitable arrangements in place to monitor and maintain the safety and quality of healthcare services to be provided in the facility;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that the operation of the facility by the applicant would be contrary to the public interest;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: another ground the Director considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the applicant is an individual—the reference to the applicant is a reference to the individual;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the applicant is a partnership—the reference to the applicant is a reference to any of the partners of the partnership;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the applicant is a company—the reference to the applicant is a reference to any of the directors of the company;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if the applicant is a body corporate other than a company—the reference to the applicant is a reference to—

subparagraph.content: any of the directors of the body; and
any of the members or officers of the body concerned in the management of the body; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if the applicant is a society—the reference to the applicant is a reference to any of the office bearers of the society.

subsection.content: A licence for a hospital is valid for a period of not more than 2 years as specified in the licence, which is to begin on the date specified in the licence for that purpose.
A licence for a day procedure centre is valid for a period of not more than 3 years as specified in the licence, which is to begin on the date specified in the licence for that purpose.

A licence for a clinic (other than a scheduled clinic) is valid for a period of not more than 5 years as specified in the licence, which is to begin on the date specified in the licence for that purpose.
A licence for a clinic that is a scheduled clinic is valid for a period of not more than 1 year as specified in the licence, which is to begin on the date specified in the licence for that purpose.
A licence for a health services establishment is valid for the period specified in the licence, which is to begin on the date specified in the licence for that purpose.
The licensee of a private healthcare facility may apply to the Director for renewal of the licence.

subsection.leadIn: The application must be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within the period before the expiry of the licence specified by the Director in writing; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Director does not specify a period in writing—not less than 6 months before the expiry of the licence.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Renewing or refusing to renew licence

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), the Director must renew the licence on receiving an application made under section 20.
The Director may refuse to renew the licence but only on a ground specified in section 38.
On renewing a licence, the Director may impose any condition in addition to, or instead of, any condition previously imposed on the licence.
The renewal of a licence takes effect on the day immediately following the day on which the licence would have expired but for the renewal.
A renewed licence for a private healthcare facility is valid for a period specified in the licence with the maximum period being the maximum period mentioned in section 19 for the facility.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application for the renewal for a licence is made under section 20; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: but for this section, the licence would expire before the application is determined.

subsection.leadIn: The licence remains in effect pending the determination unless, before the determination—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the application is withdrawn; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the licence is cancelled under section 28.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Application for variation of scale or scope of services

subsection.content: The licensee of a private healthcare facility may apply to the Director to vary the scale or scope of services specified in the licence.
On receiving the application, the Director must decide whether to approve or refuse it.
The application may be approved subject to the conditions that the Director considers appropriate.
The Director must refuse the application if the Director considers that it is not appropriate to approve the application.
Without limiting subsection (4), the Director may refuse the application on a ground specified in section 38.
A variation under this section has effect for the remainder of the period for which the licence remains in effect.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Application for variation of class of specialized service

subsection.content: The licensee of a day procedure centre may apply to the Director to vary the class of specialized service specified in the licence.
On receiving the application, the Director must decide whether to approve or refuse it.
The application may be approved subject to the conditions that the Director considers appropriate.
The Director must refuse the application if the Director considers that it is not appropriate to approve the application.
Without limiting subsection (4), the Director may refuse the application on a ground specified in section 38.
A variation under this section has effect for the remainder of the period for which the licence remains in effect.
This section applies to an application made under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: The application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be made in the form and way specified by the Director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be accompanied by the information and documents specified by the Director; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must be accompanied by the appropriate fee specified in Schedule 4.

subsection.content: This section applies to an application made under this Part in relation to which the Director has specified a period within which the applicant must provide certain information or documents in support of the application to the Director.
The application is taken to have been withdrawn if the applicant fails to provide the information or documents within the specified period.
This section applies to an application made under this Part.
If the Director refuses the application, the Director must notify the applicant in writing of the grounds for the refusal.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may by order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: suspend a licence for a private healthcare facility for a period the Director considers appropriate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cancel a licence for a private healthcare facility.

subsection.content: A licence may be suspended or cancelled only on a ground specified in section 38.
The Director may by order suspend a facility service in a private healthcare facility for a period the Director considers appropriate.
A facility service may be suspended only on a ground specified in section 38(1).

section.name: s30
section.heading: Notice of intended suspension or cancellation

subsection.leadIn: Before—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: suspending or cancelling a licence for a private healthcare facility under section 28; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: suspending a facility service under section 29,

subsection.continued: the Director must give the licensee of the facility not less than 14 days’ notice in writing of the intention to do so.

subsection.content: The ground for the intended suspension or cancellation must be set out in the notice.
However, notice is not required if the Director considers that it is in the public interest to immediately suspend the licence or service.
Also, notice is not required if the Director is satisfied that the facility or service to which the licence relates has ceased to exist or be operated.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), the Director must not suspend or cancel a licence under section 28, or suspend a facility service under section 29, without—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: first giving the licensee an opportunity to make representations to object to the suspension or cancellation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: considering the representations (if any).

subsection.leadIn: Any representations must be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within 10 days after the date of the notice given to the licensee under section 30 (or a longer period the Director allows); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the way specified in the notice.

subsection.content: This section does not apply if notice is not required under section 30(3) or (4).

section.name: s32
section.heading: Failure to comply with suspension order: operating unauthorized type of private healthcare facility

subsection.content: A licensee of a private healthcare facility commits an offence if the licensee fails to comply with an order made under section 28(1)(a) suspending a licence for the facility on the ground specified in section 38(2)(d).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the facility is operated as a hospital—on conviction on indictment to a fine of $5,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the facility is operated as a facility that is not a hospital—on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Failure to comply with suspension order: other grounds

subsection.content: A licensee of a private healthcare facility commits an offence if the licensee fails to comply with an order made under section 28(1)(a) suspending the licence for the facility on a ground specified in section 38 (other than that specified in section 38(2)(d)).
A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Failure to comply with suspension order: providing certain facility service

subsection.content: A licensee of a private healthcare facility commits an offence if the licensee fails to comply with an order made under section 29(1) suspending a facility service in the facility.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the facility is a hospital—on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the facility is not a hospital—on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

subsection.content: If the licensee of a private healthcare facility intends to cease operating the facility before the licence expires, the licensee must make a request in writing to the Director to cancel the licence.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the facility is a hospital—the request must be made not less than 3 months before the intended date of cessation of operation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the facility is not a hospital—the request must be made not less than 6 weeks before the intended date of cessation of operation.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the facility is a hospital—on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 1 year; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the facility is not a hospital—on summary conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 28(1), the Director may, on receiving the request—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: cancel the licence from the day after the intended date of cessation of operation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: impose on the licensee a requirement for the cancellation that the Director considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, contravenes a requirement imposed on the person under subsection (4)(b) and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the facility is a hospital—on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 1 year; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the facility is not a hospital—on summary conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Cancellation etc. of licence on death of individual licensee

subsection.content: This section applies to a licence for a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre, clinic or health services establishment if the licensee is an individual.
Without limiting section 28(1), the Director may by order cancel the licence on the death of the licensee.

Alternatively, the Director may, if satisfied that the conditions specified in subsection (4) are met, defer the cancellation of the licence until the expiry of 12 weeks after the date of death of the licensee.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the personal representative of the deceased licensee has made a request in writing to the Director asking for the deferment;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: the personal representative has undertaken to assume the full responsibilities of the deceased licensee in operating the facility.

subsection.content: The Director may amend the conditions of a licence for a private healthcare facility on a ground specified in section 38(1).
Before making an amendment, the Director must give the licensee not less than 14 days’ notice in writing of the intended amendment.
The ground for the intended amendment must be set out in the notice.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Grounds for action in relation to licence

subsection.leadIn: The following grounds are specified for the purposes of sections 21(2), 23(5), 24(5), 28(2), 29(2) and 37(1) in relation to a private healthcare facility—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the licensee or chief medical executive of the facility contravenes or has contravened—

subparagraph.content: this Ordinance;
a condition of the licence;
a code of practice; or
a direction;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that the practice carried on in the facility is a practice other than that specified in the licence;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.leadIn: the Director is satisfied that the facility is, or has been, used in a way not serving a purpose reasonably incidental to—

subparagraph.content: the type of facility for which the licence is issued; or
the practice or class of specialized service specified in the licence;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Director considers that the facility is being, or has been, operated in a way contrary to the public interest.

subsection.leadIn: The following additional grounds are specified for the purposes of sections 21(2), 23(5), 24(5) and 28(2) in relation to a private healthcare facility—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the licensee or chief medical executive of the facility has been convicted of an offence under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the licensee of the facility—

subparagraph.content: if a partnership—has been dissolved;
if a company—has commenced to be wound up or dissolved;
if a body corporate other than a company—has ceased to exist or carry on any business; or
if a society—has ceased to exist;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the licensee or chief medical executive of the facility has made a false statement—

subparagraph.content: in an application made under this Part; or
in any report, information or document required by the Director under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that the licensee of the facility is operating a type of facility other than that for which the licence is issued;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that the licensee of the facility has ceased to operate or have control over the facility;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that the facility has ceased to exist or be operated.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the licensee is an individual—the reference to the licensee is a reference to the individual;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the licensee is a partnership—the reference to the licensee is a reference to any of the partners of the partnership;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the licensee is a company—the reference to the licensee is a reference to any of the directors of the company;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if the licensee is a body corporate other than a company—the reference to the licensee is a reference to—

subparagraph.content: any of the directors of the body; and
any of the members or officers of the body concerned in the management of the body; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if the licensee is a society—the reference to the licensee is a reference to any of the office bearers of the society.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a decision—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to refuse to issue a licence under section 17(1)(b);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to issue a licence subject to particular conditions under section 17(3);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to refuse to renew a licence under section 21(2);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to impose particular conditions on renewing a licence under section 21(3);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to approve an application for variation of the scale or scope of services subject to particular conditions under section 23(3);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to refuse an application for variation of the scale or scope of services under section 23(4) or (5);

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to approve an application for variation of the class of specialized service subject to particular conditions under section 24(3);

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: to refuse an application for variation of the class of specialized service under section 24(4) or (5);
to suspend or cancel a licence under section 28(1);

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: to suspend a facility service under section 29(1); or

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: to amend the conditions of a licence under section 37(1).

subsection.content: An applicant or licensee of a private healthcare facility who is aggrieved by the decision may appeal to the Administrative Appeals Board.
An appeal may only be made within 14 days after the aggrieved person receives notice of the decision.

If an appeal is made under section 39, the decision appealed against is suspended as from the day on which the appeal is made until the appeal is determined, abandoned or withdrawn, unless the notice of the decision states that the decision cannot be suspended.

Otherwise, the suspension only stops when the Director gives the Administrative Appeals Board a notice in writing that the Director is of the opinion that suspending the effect of the decision is contrary to the public interest.

subsection.leadIn: A clinic is a small practice clinic if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an individual who is a registered medical practitioner or a registered dentist operates the clinic as a sole proprietor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the individual is the only registered medical practitioner or registered dentist who serves the clinic; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the individual has the exclusive right to use the premises forming the clinic.

subsection.leadIn: A clinic is also a small practice clinic if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a partnership having not more than 5 partners, each of whom is a registered medical practitioner or a registered dentist, operates the clinic;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the partners are the only registered medical practitioners or registered dentists who serve the clinic; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: one or more of the partners have the exclusive right to use the premises forming the clinic.

subsection.leadIn: A clinic is also a small practice clinic if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a company having not more than 5 directors, each of whom is a registered medical practitioner or a registered dentist, operates the clinic;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the directors are the only registered medical practitioners or registered dentists who serve the clinic; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: either the company has, or one or more of the directors have, the exclusive right to use the premises forming the clinic.

subsection.leadIn: For a clinic operated by an individual as a sole proprietor, the condition in subsection (1)(b) is satisfied if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the individual is a registered medical practitioner—the total number of days for which another registered medical practitioner takes up the duties of the individual in the clinic because of the individual’s absence from the clinic does not exceed 60 days in a calendar year; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the individual is a registered dentist—the total number of days for which another registered dentist takes up the duties of the individual in the clinic because of the individual’s absence from the clinic does not exceed 60 days in a calendar year.

subsection.leadIn: For a clinic operated by a partnership or company, the condition in subsection (2)(b) or (3)(b) is satisfied if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the partners or directors or any of them are registered medical practitioners, then, for each of the registered medical practitioners (that person)—subject to subsection (6), the total number of days for which another registered medical practitioner takes up the duties of that person in the clinic because of that person’s absence from the clinic does not exceed 60 days in a calendar year; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the partners or directors or any of them are registered dentists, then, for each of the registered dentists (that person)—subject to subsection (6), the total number of days for which another registered dentist takes up the duties of that person in the clinic because of that person’s absence from the clinic does not exceed 60 days in a calendar year.

subsection.content: The aggregate number of days for the taking up of duties by other registered medical practitioners or registered dentists for the partners or directors operating the clinic must not exceed 180 days in a calendar year.

In this section, a reference to a registered medical practitioner is a reference to a person whose name is included in Part I of the General Register kept under section 6(1) of the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161).
A person that operates, or intends to operate, a small practice clinic may ask the Director for a letter of exemption for the clinic.

subsection.leadIn: The request—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be made in the form and way specified by the Director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be accompanied by the information and documents specified by the Director;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must state the practice carried on, or to be carried on, in the clinic;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the person that operates, or intends to operate, the clinic is an individual as a sole proprietor—must be signed by the individual;

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: if the person that operates, or intends to operate, the clinic is a company—must be signed by each of the directors of the company.

subsection.leadIn: On receiving a request under section 42 from a person for a clinic with a stated practice, the Director may issue to the person a letter of exemption for the clinic if the Director is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the clinic is a small practice clinic; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: none of the individuals signing the request is for the time being in any of the following capacities (in whatever combination) for 3 or more other exempted clinics—

subparagraph.content: the sole proprietor of an exempted clinic;
a partner of a partnership operating an exempted clinic;
a director of a company operating an exempted clinic.

subsection.leadIn: A letter of exemption issued to a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must specify the clinic and practice stated in the request; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: permits the person to operate without a licence the clinic in which the practice is carried on (exemption).

subsection.content: The exemption is in force unless revoked under section 45.
The Director must refuse to issue a letter of exemption if the Director considers it inappropriate for the person making the request to carry on the practice in the clinic without a licence.
If the Director refuses to issue a letter of exemption, the Director must, in writing, inform the person making the request of the refusal and the reasons for the refusal.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Notice of intended change or cessation

subsection.leadIn: The operator of an exempted clinic must give the Director not less than 14 days’ notice in writing of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any intended change of the clinic’s operators;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any intended change of the clinic’s address;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any intended cessation of the clinic’s operation; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any intended cessation of the clinic’s operating as a small practice clinic.

subsection.content: Despite subsection (1)(a), if the change occurs because of the death or deregistration of an operator, the notice may be given within 14 days after the date of the operator’s death or deregistration.
A person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes subsection (1)(a), (b) or (c) or (2) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4.
A person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes subsection (1)(d) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be made in the form and way specified by the Director; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be accompanied by the information and documents specified by the Director.

subsection.leadIn: Despite any change of operators notified under subsection (1)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the exemption for the exempted clinic under section 43 continues to be in force (unless revoked under section 45); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the operators for the time being of the clinic may carry on the practice stated in the relevant letter of exemption in the clinic without a licence.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: deregistration (撤銷註冊) means—(a)in relation to an operator who is a registered medical practitioner—the removal of the name of the operator as a registered medical practitioner under section 19(1), 21(1) or 21A(1) of the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161) from the General Register kept under section 6(1) of that Ordinance; and(b)in relation to an operator who is a registered dentist—the removal of the name of the operator as a registered dentist under section 15, 18 or 18A of the Dentists Registration Ordinance (Cap. 156) from the General Register kept under section 7(1) of that Ordinance. (Amended 22 of 2024 s. 136)

tr.td: Amendments made by the Dentists Registration (Amendment) Ordinance 2024 (22 of 2024) to section 44(7) are partially commenced—see L.N. 146 of 2024.

subsection.content: The Director may, by notice in writing to the operator of an exempted clinic, revoke the exemption.
The exemption may be revoked only on a ground specified in section 46.
Before revoking the exemption, the Director must give the operator not less than 14 days’ notice in writing of the intended revocation and the ground for the intended revocation.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Grounds for revoking exemption
section.leadIn: The grounds for revoking an exemption for a small practice clinic under section 45 are as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an operator of the clinic contravenes or has contravened this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an operator of the clinic has been convicted of an offence under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: for a clinic operated—

subparagraph.content: by a partnership—the partnership has been dissolved;
by a company—the company has commenced to be wound up or dissolved;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that the clinic has ceased to exist or be operated;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the Director is satisfied that the clinic has ceased to be operated as a small practice clinic;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the Director considers that the clinic has been operated in a way contrary to the public interest;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the Director considers for another reason that it would be inappropriate for the exemption to continue to be in force.

subsection.content: The licensee of a private healthcare facility is wholly responsible for the operation of the facility.

subsection.leadIn: The licensee is responsible, in particular, for the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: ensuring the facility’s compliance with—

subparagraph.content: a condition of the licence;
a code of practice; and
a direction;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: setting up and enforcing rules, policies and procedures—

subparagraph.content: relating to the quality of care for, and the safety of, patients in the facility; and
for the operation of the facility.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Duty to provide information or document
section.leadIn: The licensee of a private healthcare facility must, on request, provide to the Director any information or document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that relates to the operation of the facility; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the Director considers necessary for performing the Director’s functions under this Ordinance.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Duty to appoint chief medical executive and notify of change

subsection.content: The licensee of a private healthcare facility must appoint a person to take charge of the day to day administration of the facility (chief medical executive).
A chief medical executive must satisfy all the applicable requirements under sections 51, 52 and 53.

Also, a person is ineligible for appointment as chief medical executive if the person has been convicted of an offence under this Ordinance for which the person has been sentenced to imprisonment (whether suspended or not) for a term exceeding 3 months without the option of a fine.

subsection.leadIn: If there is a change of the chief medical executive, the licensee must, before the expiry of 14 days after the change has occurred, notify the Director in writing of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the change; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the qualifications, training and experience of the chief medical executive appointed, or to be appointed, in replacement.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (4) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the facility is a hospital—on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $10,000 for each day during which the offence continues; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the facility is not a hospital—on summary conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $2,000 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Appointment for group of clinics
section.leadIn: For the purposes of section 49(1), if 4 or more clinics are operated at the same time by the same licensee, the licensee may appoint a single chief medical executive for the clinics if the licensee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has established a Medical Advisory Committee for the clinics; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has appointed for each of the clinics a registered medical practitioner, or a registered dentist, who is serving the clinic to assist the chief medical executive in carrying out the day to day administration of the clinic.

section.name: s51
section.heading: General requirements
section.leadIn: The chief medical executive of a private healthcare facility must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: possess the qualifications and experience necessary for administering a facility of that type;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be physically and mentally fit to administer a facility of that type; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be a person of integrity and good character.

subsection.content: The chief medical executive of a hospital must be a registered medical practitioner who has been registered for not less than 15 years in Hong Kong.
The chief medical executive of a hospital must not serve at the same time as a chief medical executive of another private healthcare facility.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Additional requirements for day procedure centres or clinics

subsection.content: The chief medical executive of a day procedure centre must be a registered medical practitioner or a registered dentist who has been registered for not less than 6 years in Hong Kong.
The chief medical executive of a clinic must be a registered medical practitioner or a registered dentist who has been registered for not less than 4 years in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: If the practice specified in the licence for a day procedure centre or clinic is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a dental practice only—the chief medical executive for the centre or clinic must be a registered dentist; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—the chief medical executive for the centre or clinic must be a registered medical practitioner.

subsection.leadIn: A person must not serve at the same time as the chief medical executive of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if serving only day procedure centres—more than 2 day procedure centres;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if serving only clinics—more than 3 clinics; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if serving both—more than 1 day procedure centre and 1 clinic.

subsection.leadIn: However, a person may serve as a chief medical executive of 4 or more clinics if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is appointed under section 50;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is a registered medical practitioner or a registered dentist who has been registered for not less than 8 years in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: does not serve at the same time as a chief medical executive of another private healthcare facility.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Additional requirement for combined practices
section.content: If both a medical practice and dental practice are specified in the licence for a private healthcare facility, the licensee of the facility must also appoint a registered dentist to assist the chief medical executive in carrying out the day to day administration of the dental practice.

subsection.leadIn: The chief medical executive of a private healthcare facility is, at all times when the facility is in operation, responsible for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the day to day administration of the facility; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the adoption and implementation of rules, policies and procedures concerning healthcare services provided in the facility.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the chief medical executive must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: ensure—

subparagraph.content: that every healthcare professional working in the facility has a valid practising certificate, or an enrolment that is still in force, for the professional capacity concerned; and
that every person giving healthcare services in the facility has the requisite qualifications, training and experience relevant to the healthcare services that the person provides;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: keep and maintain the following types of registers in the form and way specified by the Director—

subparagraph.content: a staff register;
a patients attendance register;
a hospital admission register (if appropriate);
any other register that the Director requires;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: supply to the Director any information or document that the Director considers necessary for performing the Director’s functions under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: perform any other duty—

subparagraph.content: prescribed by the regulations; or
specified in a code of practice.

subsection.content: This Division applies to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital.

Also, 4 or more clinics operated at the same time by the same licensee that has appointed, or that seeks to appoint, a single chief medical executive for the clinics under section 50 are collectively regarded as 1 private healthcare facility to which this Division applies.
The licensee of a private healthcare facility must establish and keep in operation a committee known as the Medical Advisory Committee for the facility.

A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $10,000 for each day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: A Medical Advisory Committee is to consist of the following members appointed by the licensee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a chairperson; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a number of other members decided by the licensee.

subsection.content: At least half of the members of the Medical Advisory Committee must be registered medical practitioners or registered dentists, including at least 1 registered medical practitioner who is not employed by, or practising in, the facility.

subsection.leadIn: The chairperson of the Medical Advisory Committee must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the practice specified in the licence for the facility is a dental practice only—a registered dentist; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—a registered medical practitioner.

subsection.content: The Medical Advisory Committee may determine its own procedure.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Function
section.leadIn: The function of the Medical Advisory Committee of a private healthcare facility is to advise the licensee of the facility on the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the qualifications of healthcare professionals for providing services in the facility and delineation of their clinical responsibilities;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all matters concerning medical diagnosis, treatment and care given, or to be given, in the facility;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: all matters concerning the quality of care for, and the safety of, patients in the facility.

subsection.content: Both the licensee and the chief medical executive of a private healthcare facility are responsible for ensuring that the advice given by the Medical Advisory Committee of the facility is properly implemented.

Without limiting subsection (1), the licensee and the chief medical executive are each primarily responsible for implementing the Medical Advisory Committee’s advice on matters that fall within their respective areas of responsibility.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Licensee to provide information
section.leadIn: The licensee of a private healthcare facility must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on request, report to the Director on any activity or advice of the Medical Advisory Committee of the facility; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide in writing to the Director a list of the members of the Medical Advisory Committee.

subsection.content: The licensee of a private healthcare facility must make available to the public information about the prices of chargeable items and services provided in the facility as prescribed by regulations for the purposes of this subsection.
The licensee must ensure that the information is provided to the public in the way prescribed by regulations for the purposes of this subsection.

The licensee of a hospital must put in place a budget estimate system to provide estimates of the fees and charges of the hospital for the treatments and procedures prescribed by regulations for the purposes of this subsection.

The licensee must ensure that each patient is provided, in the way prescribed by regulations for the purposes of this subsection, with a budget estimate form providing an estimate of the fees and charges for the treatments or procedures intended to be undertaken by the patient.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Historical statistics on fees and charges

subsection.content: The licensee of a hospital must publish historical statistics on the fees and charges for the specified treatments and procedures.
The licensee must publish the historical statistics in the way specified by the Director.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: specified treatments and procedures (指明治療及程序) means the treatments and procedures provided by the hospital that are specified by the Director for the purpose of publication under this section.

subsection.content: The licensee of a private healthcare facility must put in place a complaints handling procedure for receiving, managing and responding to complaints that are received against the facility.

subsection.leadIn: The licensee must ensure the complaints handling procedure is made known in an appropriate way to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the patients of the facility; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the case requires, persons acting on their behalf.

subsection.leadIn: The licensee must, on receiving a complaint against the facility, ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an investigation of the complaint is conducted and findings made;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the case requires, an improvement measure, whether general or specific to the complaint, is implemented; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the complainant is informed of the findings of the investigation and any improvement measure and, if the case requires, of any follow-up action taken or to be taken.

subsection.leadIn: The chief medical executive of the facility must, on request, provide to the Director a summary of the following matters that the Director considers necessary for performing the Director’s functions under this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the complaints against the facility received by the facility;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the findings of the investigations of the complaints;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the actions (including improvement measures) taken in response to the complaints.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Complaints under consideration by Complaints Committee

subsection.content: This section applies if a complaint against a private healthcare facility is made under section 82 and the Complaints Committee is considering the complaint.
The facility must fully cooperate with the Complaints Committee in providing any information or documents requested and giving any assistance necessary for concluding the case.
Without limiting subsection (2), the facility may still effect a settlement with the complainant.

tr.td: This section came into operation on 2 July 2019 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

subsection.content: This section applies in relation to a permitted facility.

subsection.leadIn: The operator of the facility must ensure that the premises of the facility are physically separated from any premises that serve a purpose not reasonably incidental to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a facility that is an exempted clinic—the practice carried on in the facility as specified in the letter of exemption for the facility; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for another facility—the type of facility for which the licence is issued.

subsection.content: The operator must also ensure that the facility is a distinct and exclusive unit and is able to perform its functions independently.
This section applies in relation to a permitted facility.

subsection.leadIn: In addition to the requirements in section 66, the operator of the facility must also ensure that the facility has a direct and separate entrance not shared with, or involving passing through, any premises that serve a purpose not reasonably incidental to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a facility that is an exempted clinic—the practice carried on in the facility as specified in the letter of exemption for the facility; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for another facility—the type of facility for which the licence is issued.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies in relation to any of the following private healthcare facilities—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a day procedure centre for which a licence is in force;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a clinic for which a licence is in force;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an exempted clinic.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), the operator of the facility must not provide to any person a medical procedure that may require the person’s continuous confinement within the facility for more than 12 hours.
If the facility is a day procedure centre, the period of continuous confinement referred to in subsection (2) must be within the same calendar day.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Registered medical practitioner resident in hospital
section.content: The licensee of a hospital must ensure that there is at least 1 registered medical practitioner resident in the hospital at all times.

section.name: s70
section.heading: “Operating room” etc. not to be used except with prior approval

subsection.content: This section applies in relation to a permitted facility.

Except with the prior approval in writing of the Director, a room, unit or section of a private healthcare facility must not bear a name or description that includes the expression “operating room”, “operation room”, “operating theatre”, “operation theatre”, “手術室”, “手術房” or “手術間”, or a similar expression.

division.name: D1
division.heading: Committee on Complaints against Private Healthcare Facilities

editorialNote.content: This Division came into operation on 2 July 2019 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This Division came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This Division came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

subsection.content: A committee is established with the name “Committee on Complaints against Private Healthcare Facilities” in English and “私營醫療機構投訴委員會” in Chinese.

subsection.leadIn: The Complaints Committee is to consist of the following members appointed by the Secretary—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a chairperson;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a deputy chairperson;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: not less than 24, and not more than 48, other members.

subsection.content: A member of the Complaints Committee is to be appointed for a term not exceeding 3 years and is eligible for reappointment on the expiry of the term.
At least half of the members of the Complaints Committee must be persons who are neither registered medical practitioners nor registered dentists.
A public officer is ineligible for appointment under subsection (2).
A member of the Complaints Committee may resign from office by giving notice in writing to the Secretary.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may terminate the appointment of a member if satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the member has become bankrupt or made a voluntary arrangement with the member’s creditors within the meaning of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the member is unable or unfit to perform the functions of a member of the Complaints Committee because of physical or mental illness or another reason.

subsection.content: Every appointment or termination under this section is to be notified in the Gazette.
Except as otherwise provided in this Ordinance, the Complaints Committee may determine its own procedure.

This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Appointment of secretary and legal adviser

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary is to appoint the following for the Complaints Committee for a period and on the terms specified in the letter of appointment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a secretary who is a public officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: one or more legal advisers.

subsection.content: A person appointed under this section may resign from office by giving notice in writing to the Secretary.

This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.

subsection.leadIn: The Complaints Committee has the following functions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to advise the Director on the policies on complaints management for private healthcare facilities;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to receive and consider facility complaints;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: to refer, in appropriate cases, facility complaints to regulatory authorities for any follow-up action;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to make recommendations to private healthcare facilities on any improvement measures;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to report to the Director any general regulatory issue arising from the facility complaints handled by the Committee;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: to publish on a regular basis summary reports on—

subparagraph.content: the facility complaints handled by the Committee; and
the recommendations made by the Committee to the Director and the private healthcare facilities concerned;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: to publicize how complaints may be made to the public.

subsection.content: The Complaints Committee may, in writing, engage any person whose technical or professional services would assist the Committee in performing its functions.

This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

subsection.content: At a meeting of the Complaints Committee, 13 members form a quorum.
The chairperson of the Complaints Committee is to preside at a meeting.
If, for any reason, the chairperson is unable to preside at a meeting, the deputy chairperson is to preside at the meeting.
If, for any reason, the deputy chairperson is also unable to preside at the meeting, the members present at the meeting are to elect from among themselves a member to preside at the meeting.
All questions for determination are to be decided by a majority of votes of the members present and voting.
If there is an equality of votes, the member who is presiding has a casting vote.

This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Declaration of interest regarding facility complaint

subsection.leadIn: If the chairperson of the Complaints Committee has an interest (whether material or not) in a facility complaint, the chairperson—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must declare the interest to the Committee as soon as practicable after the chairperson has become aware of the interest; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must not participate in any deliberation, or be involved in any determination, regarding the facility complaint.

subsection.content: If a member of the Complaints Committee has an interest in a facility complaint, the member must declare the interest to the Committee as soon as practicable after the member has become aware of the interest.

If the chairperson (or, if the chairperson is unavailable, the deputy chairperson) of the Complaints Committee decides that the member’s interest is material, the member must not participate in any deliberation, or be involved in any determination, regarding the facility complaint.

If the member has been appointed to a case panel under section 78 to deal with the facility complaint, whether or not the interest is material, the chairperson of the Complaints Committee must appoint another member of the Committee to the case panel to replace the member.

section.name: s76
section.heading: Transaction of business by circulation of papers

subsection.content: Despite section 74 and except for making a decision of the Complaints Committee under section 87(2)(b) or (4), the Committee may transact any of its business by circulation of papers without meeting.

A resolution in writing signed by a majority of the members of the Complaints Committee is as valid and effective as if it had been passed at a meeting of the Committee by the votes of the members who signed the resolution.
