division.name: D2
division.heading: Preliminary Processing Panels and Case Panels

editorialNote.content: This Division came into operation on 2 July 2019 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This Division came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This Division came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

subsection.content: The Complaints Committee is to appoint one or more panels to deal with preliminary processing of facility complaints.

A preliminary processing panel is to consist of not less than 3, and not more than 5, members appointed by the chairperson (or, if the chairperson is unavailable, the deputy chairperson) of the Complaints Committee.
Members of a preliminary processing panel must be appointed from the members of the Complaints Committee.
A preliminary processing panel must include at least 1 member who is neither a registered medical practitioner nor a registered dentist.
A member of a preliminary processing panel is to be appointed for a term not exceeding the term of his or her membership of the Complaints Committee.

If, during the processing of a facility complaint by a preliminary processing panel, the term of a member of the panel would otherwise expire, the member may continue to be a member of the panel for the purpose of completing the processing of the facility complaint.
A member of a preliminary processing panel may resign from the panel by giving notice in writing to the chairperson of the Complaints Committee.
A member of a preliminary processing panel may not be appointed as a member of a case panel.

tr.td: This section came into operation on 2 July 2019 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

subsection.content: Subject to section 84(2), the Complaints Committee may appoint one or more case panels (each with a separate convener) to deal with facility complaints.
A case panel is to consist of the convener and either 2 or 4 other members appointed by the chairperson (or, if the chairperson is unavailable, the deputy chairperson) of the Complaints Committee.
Members of a case panel must be appointed from the members of the Complaints Committee.

subsection.leadIn: A case panel must include at least—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 1 member who is a registered medical practitioner or registered dentist; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 1 member who is neither a registered medical practitioner nor a registered dentist.

subsection.content: A member of the Complaints Committee may be appointed as a member of one or more case panels at the same time.

If, during the consideration of a facility complaint by a case panel, the term of a member of the panel would otherwise expire, the member may continue to be a member of the panel for the purpose of completing the consideration of the facility complaint.

tr.td: This section came into operation on 2 July 2019 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

subsection.content: A case panel appointed to deal with a facility complaint must consider the complaint and decide whether the allegations in the complaint are substantiated.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the case panel may exercise a power under sections 88, 89 and 91 to enable it to consider the facility complaint.
The case panel is to submit its findings and recommendations to the Complaints Committee after considering the facility complaint.

division.name: D3
division.heading: Confidentiality of Information and Protection of Members of Complaints Committee

editorialNote.content: This Division came into operation on 2 July 2019 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This Division came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This Division came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

subsection.content: A member, or the secretary, of the Complaints Committee must not disclose or give to another person any information or document obtained for the purpose of considering a facility complaint.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not prohibit the member or secretary from disclosing or giving the information or document if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the disclosure or giving is necessary for performing the member’s functions (including the functions as a member of a preliminary processing panel or case panel) or secretary’s functions under this Ordinance, or for carrying into effect or doing anything authorized by this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the disclosure or giving is for making a recommendation or referral to the Director on a matter relating to a facility complaint;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the disclosure or giving is made under an order of a court; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the information, or the document or its copy (including a counterpart), has already been lawfully disclosed or made available to the public.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (3) to show that at the time of the alleged offence, the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: believed that there was lawful authority for the person to disclose or give the information or document to the other person and the person had no reasonable cause to believe otherwise; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: did not know and had no reasonable cause to believe that the information or document disclosed or given was confidential.

This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Protection of members of Complaints Committee

subsection.content: A member of the Complaints Committee is not civilly liable for any act done, or omitted to be done, by the member in good faith in performing or purportedly performing the member’s function (including the functions as a member of a preliminary processing panel or case panel) under this Ordinance.

For the purposes of the law of defamation, if the member makes a comment, or publishes a matter, relating to a facility complaint in any communication, report or statement (in writing or otherwise) for performing the member’s functions under this Ordinance, the comment or publication is absolutely privileged.

subsection.leadIn: The following persons may make a complaint to the Complaints Committee against a private healthcare facility for which a licence is in force—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a patient of the facility;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a next of kin of the patient;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a substitute decision maker of the patient;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person authorized by the patient in writing to make a complaint;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the personal representative of the patient.

subsection.leadIn: The facility complaint—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be made in the form and way specified by the Director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be substantiated by specific facts;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.leadIn: must be accompanied by a consent to the facility to disclose any information about the individual to whom the complaint relates to any one or more of the following (as the case requires)—

subparagraph.content: the Complaints Committee;
a medical professional or other expert appointed by the Complaints Committee to assist in investigating the complaint;
the Director;
an authorized officer.

subsection.content: If a settlement is effected between the complainant and the facility before the case is concluded by the Complaints Committee, the complainant may, in writing, notify the Committee of the settlement and withdraw the complaint.

tr.td: This section came into operation on 2 July 2019 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

subsection.content: If a facility complaint against a private healthcare facility is received, it must be processed by a preliminary processing panel.

If the subject matter of the facility complaint had been handled by the facility before the complaint is made under section 82, the preliminary processing panel may, by notice in writing, require the facility to provide to the Complaints Committee, within the period specified in the notice, all correspondence between the complainant and the facility relating to the matter.

subsection.leadIn: If the subject matter of the facility complaint had not been handled by the facility before the complaint is made under section 82, the preliminary processing panel may, by notice in writing, require the facility to, within the period specified in the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: conduct an investigation of the complaint;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make a substantive reply to the complainant; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provide to the Complaints Committee the result of the investigation and the reply to the complainant.

subsection.leadIn: The preliminary processing panel is to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: compile any documents received under subsections (2) and (3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: identify whether a ground referred to in section 84(2) is found in relation to the facility complaint; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: report to the Complaints Committee on the result of the preliminary processing of the complaint.

subsection.content: If a private healthcare facility fails to comply with a requirement made of it under subsection (3), the Complaints Committee may refer the case to the Director for any further action.

If the complainant referred to in subsection (3) is satisfied with the reply made by the facility after the investigation, the complainant may, in writing, notify the Complaints Committee of the fact and withdraw the facility complaint.

A preliminary processing panel may transact any of its business by circulation of papers without meeting, and a resolution signed by a majority of the members of the panel is as valid and effective as if it had been passed at a meeting of the panel.

section.name: s84
section.heading: Consideration of facility complaint by case panel

subsection.content: On receiving a report from the preliminary processing panel under section 83(4)(c), the Complaints Committee must appoint a case panel to consider the facility complaint unless it has been withdrawn.

subsection.leadIn: However, the Complaints Committee may refuse to appoint a case panel to consider a facility complaint if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the subject matter of the complaint is not related to compliance with this Ordinance or a code of practice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the event to which the complaint relates occurred more than 2 years before the day on which the complaint is made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the complaint is made anonymously or the complainant cannot be identified or traced;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the subject matter of the complaint has been referred to, or is being considered by, the coroner;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the complaint relates to a commercial matter;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the complainant has instituted legal proceedings for the same subject matter; or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the Committee considers that the complaint is frivolous or groundless.

subsection.content: If the Complaints Committee refuses to appoint a case panel under subsection (2), the Committee is to close the complaint case and inform the complainant in writing accordingly.

This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

section.name: s85
section.heading: Recommendation for alternative dispute resolution
section.leadIn: A case panel may recommend the Complaints Committee to advise the complainant of a facility complaint to seek an alternative dispute resolution to an issue it finds in considering the complaint, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the issue is not related to compliance with this Ordinance or a code of practice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the case panel considers that the outcome sought by the complainant for the issue is unlikely to be satisfied by a decision of the Committee; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the case panel considers that resolution of the issue by the Committee is neither efficient nor practical.

This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

section.name: s86
section.heading: Conclusion of complaints and recommendations of case panel

subsection.content: A case panel must, after considering a facility complaint, make one or more of the recommendations specified in subsection (2) to the Complaints Committee for its consideration.

subsection.leadIn: The recommendations are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the case panel finds that the complaint is not substantiated—to close the complaint case; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the case panel finds that the complaint (or any part of it) is substantiated—

subparagraph.content: to refer the complaint to another regulatory authority for the investigation of the complaint and any follow-up action;
to advise the facility on any improvement measures; and
to report to the Director any regulatory issue arising from the facts of the case or the case panel’s observations during consideration of the complaint.

This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

section.name: s87
section.heading: Complaints Committee’s consideration of case panel’s recommendations

subsection.leadIn: If the Complaints Committee approves the recommendations made by a case panel under section 86 on a facility complaint, the Committee is to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: close the complaint case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: inform the complainant in writing of—

subparagraph.content: the decision of the Committee; and
any action taken or to be taken in relation to the private healthcare facility according to the recommendations approved by the Committee.

subsection.leadIn: If the Complaints Committee does not approve the recommendations (or any of them) made by a case panel on a facility complaint, the Committee may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: return the complaint case or the relevant issue to the case panel for review; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make its own decision in relation to the complaint case or relevant issue at a meeting of the Committee.

subsection.leadIn: If, after a return mentioned in subsection (2)(a), the case panel makes only a recommendation that the Complaints Committee approves, the Committee is to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: close the complaint case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: inform the complainant in writing of—

subparagraph.content: the decision of the Committee; and
any action taken or to be taken in relation to the private healthcare facility according to the recommendations approved by the Committee.

subsection.content: If, after a return mentioned in subsection (2)(a), the case panel makes a recommendation that the Complaints Committee does not approve, the Committee may make its own decision in relation to the complaint case or relevant issue at a meeting of the Committee.
For the purpose of making a decision under subsection (2)(b) or (4), the Complaints Committee may exercise a power under sections 88, 89 and 91 to enable it to consider the facility complaint.

subsection.leadIn: After a decision is made under subsection (2)(b) or (4), the Complaints Committee is to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: close the complaint case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: inform the complainant in writing of—

subparagraph.content: the decision of the Committee; and
any action taken or to be taken in relation to the private healthcare facility that the Committee considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of considering a facility complaint, the Complaints Committee, the preliminary processing panel processing the complaint, or the case panel dealing with the complaint, may, by notice in writing, require a person—

paragraph.name: a

paragraph.name: b

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (1) must indicate the purpose of obtaining the information or document.
