This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

subsection.content: For the purpose of considering a facility complaint, the Complaints Committee or the case panel dealing with the complaint, may interview any person who is, or may be, able to provide information or other assistance to the Committee or case panel in relation to the complaint.
An interview under this section must be conducted in private.
Subject to subsections (4) and (5), the Complaints Committee or case panel may decide who may be present at an interview.

subsection.leadIn: If a person interviewed under this section is under the age of 16 years, or is known to the Complaints Committee or case panel to be a mentally incapacitated person, the person must be interviewed in the presence of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s parent or guardian;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an adult who has an interest in the welfare of the person and is, in the opinion of the Committee or case panel, an appropriate person to be present at the interview; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: another person whom the Committee or case panel considers appropriate in a particular case.

subsection.content: A person interviewed by the Complaints Committee or case panel has the right to be accompanied by a solicitor or counsel at the interview.
However, a solicitor or counsel does not have a right of audience before the Complaints Committee or case panel at an interview unless he or she is the person to be interviewed under this section.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: mentally incapacitated person (精神上無行為能力的人) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136).

tr.td: This section came into operation on 2 July 2019 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

subsection.content: The Complaints Committee or the case panel dealing with a facility complaint must make a record of every interview conducted by the Committee or case panel.
The record is to be kept for the period that is necessary for performing the Complaints Committee’s functions under this Ordinance.

tr.td: This section came into operation on 2 July 2019 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

section.name: s91
section.heading: Obtaining professional opinions
section.content: For the purpose of considering a facility complaint, the Complaints Committee or the case panel dealing with the complaint may obtain an opinion relating to the subject matter of the complaint by a regulatory authority, medical professional or another expert.

tr.td: This section came into operation on 2 July 2019 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a hospital)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a day procedure centre)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a private healthcare facility that is a clinic)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

section.name: s92
section.heading: Prohibited use of titles or descriptions

subsection.leadIn: Except with the prior approval in writing of the Director, or except as provided or permitted by any other law, no premises (other than a permitted facility) may bear a title or description—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that includes an expression specified in Schedule 8, or a similar expression; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that suggests that the services provided in the premises are medical services provided in a private healthcare facility.

subsection.content: Except with the prior approval in writing of the Director, or except as provided or permitted by any other law, a day procedure centre must not bear a title or description that includes the expression “hospital” or “醫院”, or a similar expression.

Except with the prior approval in writing of the Director, or except as provided or permitted by any other law, a clinic must not bear a title or description that includes the expression “hospital”, “day procedure centre”, “醫院” or “日間醫療中心”, or a similar expression.

Except with the prior approval in writing of the Director, or except as provided or permitted by any other law, a health services establishment must not bear a title or description that includes the expression “hospital”, “day procedure centre”, “clinic”, “醫院”, “日間醫療中心” or “診所”, or a similar expression.

A person who uses a title or description for any premises in contravention of subsection (1), (2), (3) or (4) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.leadIn: This section does not apply in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: premises managed or controlled by a specified authority; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a day procedure centre, clinic or health services establishment primarily used for teaching or research relating to medicine or dentistry and that is managed or controlled by a scheduled university.

section.name: s93
section.heading: Making false or misleading statements or representations

subsection.leadIn: If a person makes a statement or representation in an application under this Ordinance, or in a request under section 42, or in a notice under section 44, or to the Complaints Committee, the person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the statement or representation is false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person knows or is reckless as to whether the statement or representation is false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: Complaints Committee (投訴委員會) includes a preliminary processing panel and a case panel.

section.name: s94
section.heading: Offences by bodies corporate or members of unincorporated bodies

subsection.content: If an offence under this Ordinance is committed by a body corporate or by a person as a member of an unincorporated body, and it is proved that the offence has been committed with the consent or connivance of, or is attributable to the neglect or omission of a person specified in subsection (2), that person also commits the offence.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, at the time of the offence, was one of the following persons, is a person specified for subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an offence committed by a body corporate—a director, shadow director, company secretary, principal officer or manager, or any other person concerned in the management, of the body corporate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an offence committed by a member of an unincorporated body—a partner or office holder in, or a member or manager of, or any other person concerned in the management of, the unincorporated body;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in a case mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b)—a person purporting to act in the capacity of a person referred to in that paragraph.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: company secretary (公司秘書) includes any person occupying the position of company secretary, by whatever name called;

principal officer (主要人員), in relation to a body corporate, means—(a)a person employed or engaged by the body corporate who, either alone or jointly with one or more other persons, is responsible under the immediate authority of the directors of the body corporate for the conduct of the business of the body corporate; or(b)a person employed or engaged by the body corporate who, under the immediate authority of a director of the body corporate or a person to whom paragraph (a) applies, performs managerial functions in respect of the body corporate;

shadow director (幕後董事), in relation to a body corporate, means a person under whose directions or instructions (excluding advice given in a professional capacity) the directors, or a majority of the directors, of the body corporate are accustomed to act.

section.name: s95
section.heading: Defence
section.leadIn: In any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance, the person charged is entitled to be acquitted if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that—

subparagraph.content: the commission of the offence was due to a cause beyond the person’s control; and

subparagraph.leadIn: the person took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence by—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the person; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: any person under the person’s control; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: compound any compoundable offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if proceedings for a compoundable offence have been commenced, apply for a stay and compound the proceedings.

subsection.content: If the Director compounds any compoundable offence under subsection (1), the Director must serve a notice in writing on the person reasonably suspected of having committed the offence, specifying the amount of money payable as a penalty for the offence.
A penalty payable under subsection (2) is recoverable as a civil debt due to the Government.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: compoundable offence (可罰款抵罪的罪行) means—(a)an offence under section 11(2), 44(3), 49(5), 57(2), 80(3), 118(6) or 119(4); or(b)another offence under this Ordinance or the regulations that is specified by the Secretary as an offence to which this section applies.

section.name: s97
section.heading: Time limit for prosecution
section.content: Despite section 26 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227), a complaint may be made or an information laid in respect of an offence under this Ordinance (except for an indictable offence) within 12 months after the offence is discovered by, or comes to the notice of, the Director.

subsection.content: The Director may in writing authorize a public officer to exercise any power (other than that under section 105) of the Director under this Ordinance.
An authorized officer may be assisted by any person the officer reasonably requires to exercise the power.
The Director may appoint one or more advisory committees to advise on any matter relating to the regulation of private healthcare facilities.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: appoint the chairperson and other members of an advisory committee; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: determine the composition of a committee.

subsection.content: An advisory committee may determine its own procedure.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Fees and allowances to members of committees
section.content: The Director may pay a member of a committee appointed under this Ordinance the fees and allowances determined by the Financial Secretary.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Secretary may specify category of health services establishment

subsection.content: The Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify a category of health services establishment in Schedule 9.
A notice under subsection (1) is subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s102
section.heading: Director may issue code of practice

subsection.leadIn: The Director may issue a code of practice about any of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the equipment, fittings and furnishings in private healthcare facilities;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the management and staffing arrangement of private healthcare facilities;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the quality of care for, and the safety of, patients in private healthcare facilities;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other matters for protecting the health and interests of individuals receiving healthcare services in private healthcare facilities.

subsection.leadIn: A code of practice may include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a standard; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a specification.

subsection.leadIn: A code of practice may refer to, apply or incorporate a document that has been formulated, published or specified by the Director either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as in force at the time when the document is referred to, applied or incorporated; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as amended, formulated, published or specified from time to time.

subsection.leadIn: If a code of practice is issued, the Director must by notice published in the Gazette—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identify the code of practice; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the date on which the code of practice is to take effect.

subsection.content: The Director may from time to time revise or revoke the whole, or any part, of a code of practice issued under subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: If a code of practice is revised or revoked under subsection (5), the Director must by notice published in the Gazette—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identify the code of practice, or any part so revised or revoked; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the date on which the revision or revocation is to take effect.

subsection.leadIn: A code of practice must be made available for public inspection free of charge—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: through the Internet; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the office of the Director, or any other Government offices as the Director may direct, during normal office hours.

subsection.content: A code of practice issued (whether revised or not) under this section is not subsidiary legislation.
To avoid doubt, different codes of practice may be issued under this section for different purposes under this Ordinance.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Director may specify certain medical procedures in code of practice

subsection.content: Despite section 5 and the inclusion of a medical procedure in column 2 of Schedule 3, the Director may, in a code of practice, specify a medical procedure that may only be carried out in a hospital.
Despite section 5, if a code of practice specifies that a medical procedure may only be carried out in a hospital, the procedure may not be carried out in a day procedure centre.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, by notice in writing, give any direction to a person, or a private healthcare facility for which a licence is in force, specifying the details as to how the person or facility is to comply with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a code of practice.

subsection.content: If the direction is given to a private healthcare facility, the notice must be served on the licensee or chief medical executive of the facility.
A notice under subsection (1) must indicate a period within which the direction must be complied with.
The Director may exempt in writing any person from any of the provisions of a code of practice.
The Director may impose conditions on an exemption given under subsection (1), and those conditions must be set out in the exemption.
The Director may at any time revoke an exemption given under subsection (1) if it appears to the Director that a condition of the exemption has been contravened.
The Director may specify the form of a document required for the purposes of this Ordinance.
The Director may specify more than one form of the document, whether as alternatives or to provide for different circumstances.

subsection.leadIn: A form specified under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be completed in accordance with the directions and instructions that are specified in the form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the completed form is required to be provided to the Director or another person—must be provided in the way specified in the form.

section.name: s107
section.heading: Director to establish and maintain registers

subsection.leadIn: The Director must, for the purposes of this Ordinance, establish and maintain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a register of all private healthcare facilities for which licences are in force; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a register of all small practice clinics for which exemptions under section 43 are in force.

subsection.content: A register under subsection (1) may be kept in a form, and may contain the information, that the Director considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: The registers must be made available for a member of the public to ascertain the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether a private healthcare facility is operated with a licence that is in force;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether a small practice clinic is operated with an exemption under section 43 that is in force.

subsection.leadIn: The registers must be made available for public inspection free of charge—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: through the Internet; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the office of the Director, or any other Government offices as the Director may direct, during normal office hours.

subsection.content: If the original of a certificate of licence, or a letter of exemption under section 43, is lost, stolen, destroyed, defaced or damaged, the Director may, on application, issue to the operator of the private healthcare facility a duplicate of the certificate or letter to replace the original.

subsection.leadIn: The application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be accompanied by the appropriate fee specified in Schedule 4; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be accompanied by the original document if it is still available to the operator.

subsection.content: A duplicate issued under subsection (1) has the same effect as, and is equivalent to, the original document before replacement.
On the issue of a duplicate, the original document ceases to have effect.
This section applies if a person fails to pay, within the time specified by the Director, the appropriate fee (or any part of it) for an application under this Ordinance.

Without affecting other provisions of this Ordinance, the Director may, by notice in writing, order the person to pay a surcharge not exceeding 5% of the unpaid amount within the time specified by the Director for the purposes of this subsection.

section.name: s110
section.heading: Fees paid not refundable
section.content: Any fee paid under this Ordinance is not refundable.

section.name: s111
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: contravention (違反事項) means a contravention of any of the following—(a)this Ordinance;(b)a condition of the licence;(c)a code of practice;(d)a direction.

section.name: s112
section.heading: Director may require information and documents

subsection.content: This section applies if the Director has reasonable cause to suspect that a person has, or may have, possession or control of information or documents in relation to a matter that constitutes, or may constitute, a contravention.

For the purpose of conducting an investigation on the contravention, the Director may, by notice in writing, require the person to provide or produce the information or documents that are necessary for the investigation.
The notice must indicate the subject matter and purpose of the investigation.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may also specify in the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time and place at which any information or document is to be provided or produced; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the form and way in which any information or document is to be provided or produced.

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, refuses or fails to provide or produce any information or document required by the Director under subsection (2).

A person who commits an offence under subsection (5) is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $2,000 for each day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: If a person provides or produces any information or document to the Director under subsection (2), the person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the information or document is false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person knows or is reckless as to whether the information or document is false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (7) is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Power of entry to private healthcare facility without warrant
section.leadIn: The Director or an authorized officer may, without a warrant issued by a magistrate, enter a private healthcare facility for which a licence is in force at any reasonable time and exercise a power specified in section 116 for ascertaining—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: whether the following is complied with—

subparagraph.content: this Ordinance;
a condition of the licence;
a code of practice;
a direction; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the safety, legality, quality and appropriateness of—

subparagraph.content: the services provided in the facility; or
the medical procedures carried out in the facility.

subsection.content: The Director or an authorized officer may, with a warrant issued under subsection (2), enter, by the use of reasonable force if necessary, any premises and exercise a power specified in section 116 in relation to the premises and do any other thing necessary for investigating whether a contravention is being, or has been, committed.

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate may issue a warrant authorizing the Director or an authorized officer to enter the premises and exercise a power specified in section 116 in relation to the premises only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the magistrate is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that—

subparagraph.content: a contravention is being, or has been, committed on the premises; or
there is on the premises anything that constitutes, or is likely to constitute, evidence that a contravention is being, or has been, committed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the magistrate is also satisfied that—

subparagraph.content: it is not practicable to communicate with a person entitled to grant entry to the premises;
such a person has unreasonably refused entry to the premises by the Director or an authorized officer;
the Director or an authorized officer apprehends on reasonable grounds that entry to the premises is unlikely to be granted unless a warrant is issued; or
the purpose of entry to the premises would be frustrated unless the Director or an authorized officer arriving at the premises can secure immediate entry.

subsection.content: A person entering premises under a warrant issued under subsection (2) must, if requested, produce the warrant for inspection.
Unless otherwise specified by the magistrate, a warrant issued under subsection (2) continues in force until the purpose for the entry has been satisfied.

A warrant issued under subsection (2) must be executed at a reasonable hour unless the Director or an authorized person executing it believes that to execute it at a reasonable hour could frustrate the purpose of the execution.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, if satisfied that the conditions in subsection (2) are met—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter any premises and exercise a power specified in section 116 in relation to the premises and do any other thing necessary for investigating whether a contravention is being, or has been, committed; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: authorize an authorized officer to exercise the powers mentioned in paragraph (a).

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that—

subparagraph.content: a contravention is being, or has been, committed on the premises; or
there is on the premises anything that constitutes, or is likely to constitute, evidence that a contravention is being, or has been, committed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that—

subparagraph.content: immediate entry into the premises is necessary for protecting public health; or
it is not reasonably practicable to obtain a warrant in the circumstances of the case.

subsection.content: If the person entering the premises is an authorized officer, the person must, if requested, produce the Director’s authorization for inspection.

section.name: s116
section.heading: Powers after entry
section.leadIn: The powers specified for the purposes of sections 113, 114(1), 115(1) and 133 are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to inspect and search the premises;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to examine, remove and detain any apparatus, appliance, equipment, instrument, substance, record or document used or found on the premises;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to examine, take samples of, remove, detain and demand any part or produce of a human body found on the premises;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to observe any procedure or test provided on the premises; (Amended 22 of 2024 s. 137)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to take any photograph and video recording on the premises; (Amended 22 of 2024 s. 137)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to observe, with a patient’s consent, the services provided to the patient in the facility;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to do anything necessary for ascertaining whether this Ordinance, a condition of the licence, a code of practice or a direction has been complied with;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: to seize and detain anything which is, or which appears to be or to contain, or which is likely to be or to contain, evidence of the commission of a contravention, or to take such steps as appear to be necessary for preserving such thing or preventing interference with it; and
to require any person present on the premises to provide any assistance or information necessary to enable the Director or an authorized officer to perform their functions under this Ordinance.

section.name: s117
section.heading: Obstructing Director or authorized officer in performing functions

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if the person wilfully obstructs or delays the Director or an authorized officer in performing any of their functions, or doing anything they are authorized to do, under this Ordinance.

A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $10,000 for each day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Secretary may require information from licensees

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may, for the formulation of healthcare policies, require the licensee of a private healthcare facility to provide any information that the Secretary considers necessary in relation to the facility with regard to the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the costing and financing of healthcare services and manpower;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the provision of healthcare services and manpower.

subsection.content: The Secretary may in writing authorize a public officer to exercise the power under subsection (1), and the officer may be assisted by any person the officer reasonably requires to exercise the power.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary must not disclose information provided under subsection (1) to any person other than the following persons, and the information may only be disclosed and used for the purpose of formulation of healthcare policies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Hospital Authority;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a public officer authorized under subsection (2);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person referred to in subsection (2) who assists the public officer.

subsection.content: The information disclosed to the Hospital Authority may only be disclosed in the form of aggregate data that does not allow the identity of the patient or the private healthcare facility to be ascertained.

subsection.leadIn: Information in relation to a patient required under subsection (1) may only be any or all of the following information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: unique record number;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: age;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: sex;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: type of care received and procedure carried out;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: type of ward;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: admission date;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: date of discharge or death;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: diagnosis on discharge;
bill items and their amounts;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: any other information that the Secretary may reasonably require.

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, refuses or fails to provide any information required by the Secretary under subsection (1).

A person who commits an offence under subsection (6) is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4 and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $2,000 for each day during which the offence continues.
This section applies to a public officer who performs any function under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any information has come to the knowledge, or any document has come into the possession, of the public officer in the course of performing any function under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the information or document relates to the condition, treatment or diagnosis of another person, or a trade or business secret,

subsection.continued: the public officer must not disclose or give the information or document to a third person.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) does not prohibit the public officer from disclosing or giving the information or document if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the disclosure or giving is necessary for performing the public officer’s functions under this Ordinance, or for carrying into effect or doing anything authorized by this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the disclosure or giving is made with the consent in writing of the person from whom the information or document was obtained or received and, if the information relates to another person, with the consent in writing also of that other person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the disclosure or giving is made under an order of a court;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the disclosure or giving is made in the form of an anonymous summary compiled to prevent particulars relating to the business, identity, or trading particulars, of the following persons from being ascertained—

subparagraph.content: any of those persons who have produced or provided the information;
any persons to whom the information relates;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the disclosure or giving is made for the purpose of seeking advice from, or giving advice by, a counsel or a solicitor or any other professional adviser, acting or proposing to act in a professional capacity in connection with any matter arising under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the information or document has already been lawfully disclosed or made available to the public; or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the disclosure or giving is made to prevent or mitigate a significant risk of injury to a person.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (4) to show that at the time of the alleged offence, the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: believed that there was lawful authority for the person to disclose or give the information or document to the other person and the person had no reasonable cause to believe otherwise; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: did not know and had no reasonable cause to believe that the information or document disclosed or given was confidential.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: anonymous summary (隱名摘要) means a summary compiled from similar information obtained or received from a number of persons.

subsection.content: A public officer is not civilly liable for an act done or omitted to be done by the public officer in good faith in performing or purportedly performing a function under this Ordinance.
Subsection (1) does not affect any liability of the Government for the act or omission.

subsection.leadIn: A notice or other document (however described) required to be given or sent under this Ordinance is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, given or sent if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for the Director—

subparagraph.content: it is addressed to the Director and delivered to the Director’s principal office; or
it is sent to the Director by post addressed to the address specified by the Director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for an individual—

subparagraph.content: it is addressed to the individual and delivered personally to the individual; or
it is sent to the individual by post addressed to the individual at the individual’s last known address;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: for a partnership—

subparagraph.content: it is addressed to the partnership and delivered by hand to a place in Hong Kong at which the partnership carries on business, and given to a person apparently concerned in the management of, or apparently employed by, the partnership; or
it is sent to the partnership by post addressed to the partnership at the partnership’s last known address;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: for a company—

subparagraph.content: it is addressed to the company and delivered to an officer of the company by hand;
it is left at, or sent by post to, the company’s registered office within the meaning of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622); or
it is sent to the company by post addressed to the company at the company’s last known address; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: for a body corporate other than a company, or an unincorporated body of persons other than a partnership—

subparagraph.content: it is addressed to the body and delivered by hand to a place in Hong Kong at which the body carries on business, and given to a person apparently concerned in the management of, or apparently employed by, the body; or
it is sent to the body by post addressed to the body at the body’s last known address.

subsection.leadIn: A notice or document given or sent in accordance with subsection (1) is taken to have been served on the addressee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if it is delivered to the addressee personally—on the day of service; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it is sent to the addressee’s address for service or the addressee’s last known address by post—at the time at which the notice or document would be delivered in the ordinary course of post.

subsection.content: The Secretary may make regulations for the better carrying out of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the Secretary may by regulation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide for administrative procedures, forms, and registers for the purposes of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide for the management and control of private healthcare facilities;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provide for the standards of accommodation, staffing, equipment, delivery of care, and operation or provision of any services, in private healthcare facilities;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: provide for appointments, qualifications, duties and responsibilities of licensees and chief medical executives and other personnel of private healthcare facilities;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: provide for the assessment on attainment of standards of, or compliance with requirements by, private healthcare facilities, and the establishment or adoption of any scheme of accreditation for making the assessment;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: provide for the records, books, accounts, audits and reports relating to private healthcare facilities to be made, kept or submitted to the Director;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: prescribe the price information to be provided, and the way it is to be provided, by the licensee of a private healthcare facility for the purposes of section 61;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: prescribe the treatments and procedures for which estimates of fees and charges are to be provided, and the way they are to be provided, by the licensee of a hospital for the purposes of section 62;
provide for any other matters affecting the regulation of private healthcare facilities generally;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: prescribe anything that is to be or may be prescribed by a regulation made under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: provide for any incidental, supplemental, evidential, consequential, savings and transitional provisions that are necessary and expedient in consequence of the regulations.

subsection.content: Regulations made under this section may prescribe offences for contravention of the regulations, punishable by a fine, imprisonment or both, and provide for defences to any such offences.

The maximum fine that may be prescribed by a regulation for an offence is level 6 and the maximum imprisonment is 2 years. In addition, in the case of a continuing offence, a further fine not exceeding $10,000 for each day during which the offence continues may be prescribed.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 28(5) of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1), if a provision of any of the regulations made under this section is to commence on a day to be notified in the Gazette—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the notice may fix different days for the provision to commence for different purposes; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: different notices may fix different days for the provision to commence for different purposes.

section.name: s123
section.heading: Amendment of Schedules
section.content: The Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend Schedules 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10.

section.name: s124
section.heading: Interpretation of Part 9
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: certificate of registration (註冊證明書) means a certificate of registration issued under section 3 of the Hospitals, Nursing Homes and Maternity Homes Registration Ordinance (Cap. 165);
clinic licence (診所牌照) means a licence for a clinic;
day procedure centre licence (日間醫療中心牌照) means a licence for a day procedure centre;
exemption (豁免) means an exemption granted under section 128(4)(a) for a scheduled nursing home as exempted premises;
existing day procedure centre (現有日間醫療中心)—see section 135(1)(a);
hospital licence (醫院牌照) means a licence for a hospital;

registered hospital (註冊醫院) means a hospital, as defined in the Hospitals, Nursing Homes and Maternity Homes Registration Ordinance (Cap. 165), for which a certificate of registration of a hospital is issued;
registered person (註冊人士) means the person to whom a certificate of registration is issued;
scheduled nursing home (附表護養院) means a nursing home listed in Schedule 10 for which a certificate of registration of a nursing home is valid as at 1 April 2017.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Application for Hospital Licence during Specified Period

section.name: s125
section.heading: Application for licence where hospital already registered

subsection.leadIn: This section applies in relation to a person’s application for a hospital licence made under section 13 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person is a registered person in relation to a registered hospital;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the certificate of registration is valid at the time of the application; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the application is made within the period specified by the Director under subsection (7).

subsection.content: If the certificate of registration states that the premises of the registered hospital consist of a main hospital (main premises) and other facilities (associated premises), the registered person may, in making the application, apply only for a single licence for the main premises and all, or such part, of the associated premises that may be included in the application under subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: The associated premises that may be included in the application are those that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: do not form part of the premises of a day procedure centre or an outreach facility; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: are used, or intended to be used, for—

subparagraph.content: providing medical services to patients, without lodging; or
carrying out minor medical procedures on patients, without lodging.

subsection.content: Subsection (2) applies even if the main premises and associated premises as a whole do not meet the description of premises in section 8.

Division 1 of Part 3 applies in relation to the application as if the main premises and the associated premises included in the application were one single private healthcare facility that is a hospital.

If a person applies for a hospital licence under section 13 in reliance on this section (whether or not associated premises are covered in the licence), the application needs only to be accompanied by the fee specified in item 12 of Schedule 4.
The Director may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify a period within which an application for a hospital licence under section 13 may be made in reliance on this section.

section.name: s126
section.heading: Application for licence where scheduled nursing home already registered

subsection.leadIn: This section applies in relation to a person’s application for a hospital licence made under section 13 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person is a registered person in relation to a scheduled nursing home;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the certificate of registration is valid at the time of the application; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the application is made within the period specified by the Director under subsection (3).

subsection.content: If a person applies for a hospital licence under section 13 in reliance on this section, the application needs only to be accompanied by the fee specified in item 12 of Schedule 4.
The Director may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify a period within which an application for a hospital licence under section 13 may be made in reliance on this section.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a hospital licence issued under section 17(1) in reliance on section 125;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the first renewal of the licence; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the renewed licence after the first renewal only.

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, for the purposes of this Ordinance, the main premises and the associated premises covered by the licence constitute one private healthcare facility that is a hospital, and the provisions of this Ordinance apply accordingly.

If, at any time during the validity period of the licence, a specified event occurs in relation to particular associated premises (particular premises) covered by the licence, the particular premises cease to be covered by the licence immediately.

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (3), each of the following events is a specified event—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a licence is issued under section 17 for particular premises covered by the licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director approves an application under section 23 from the person to whom the licence is issued to remove particular premises from the coverage of the licence.

division.name: D3
division.heading: Application for Exemption of Nursing Home during Specified Period

section.name: s128
section.heading: Application for exemption where nursing home already registered

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person is a registered person in relation to a scheduled nursing home on premises (registered premises) stated in the certificate of registration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person has applied for, but has not been granted, any of the following in relation to all, or a part, of the registered premises (relevant premises)—

subparagraph.content: a licence under the Residential Care Homes (Elderly Persons) Ordinance (Cap. 459);
a licence under the Residential Care Homes (Persons with Disabilities) Ordinance (Cap. 613);
a licence for a private healthcare facility under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: The person may apply to the Director for an exemption in relation to the home on the relevant premises.

subsection.leadIn: An application for an exemption must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: made within the period specified by the Director under subsection (7);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: made in the form and way specified by the Director; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: accompanied by the information and documents specified by the Director.

subsection.leadIn: On receiving the application, the Director may in writing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: grant the exemption for all, or a part, of the relevant premises (exempted premises) and impose any conditions on the exemption that the Director considers appropriate in relation to the accommodation, staffing or equipment of the home; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse to grant the exemption if the Director considers it inappropriate for the home to be exempted.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (4)(b), the Director may refuse to grant the exemption if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that the applicant is a fit and proper person to operate or exercise control over the home; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director is not satisfied that a registered nurse will be resident in the home for the validity period of the exemption.

subsection.content: An exemption permits the person to whom it is granted to operate the home on the exempted premises without a licence, and section 10(1) does not apply to the person in relation to the person’s operation of the home on the exempted premises.
The Director may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify a period within which an application for an exemption may be made.

tr.td: Beginning on 2 January 2020 and ending on 30 April 2020—see Cap. 633 sub. leg. E.

subsection.leadIn: An exemption in relation to the operation of a scheduled nursing home on the exempted premises is valid for the period beginning on the date specified by the Director in the exemption and ending on the earliest of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the day on which it is revoked under section 130 for all, or a part, of the exempted premises;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the day on which any of the following licences is issued for all, or a part, of the exempted premises—

subparagraph.content: a licence under the Residential Care Homes (Elderly Persons) Ordinance (Cap. 459);
a licence under the Residential Care Homes (Persons with Disabilities) Ordinance (Cap. 613);
a licence for a private healthcare facility under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the Secretary has appointed a day under section 134 for the expiry of this Division—that day.

subsection.content: If an exemption ceases to be valid under subsection (1) for only part of the exempted premises, the exemption continues to be valid for the remaining part of the exempted premises.
The Director may by notice revoke an exemption for all, or a part, of the exempted premises.
However, an exemption may be revoked only on a ground specified in section 131.
Before revoking an exemption, the Director must give the person to whom it was granted not less than 14 days’ notice in writing of the intended revocation and the ground for the intended revocation.

section.name: s131
section.heading: Grounds for revoking exemption
section.leadIn: The grounds for revoking an exemption in relation to the operation of a scheduled nursing home are as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a ground that would entitle the Director to refuse to grant the exemption;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contravention of a condition imposed by the Director under section 128(4)(a); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the conviction of the person to whom the exemption was granted of an offence under this Ordinance in relation to the home.

section.name: s132
section.heading: Director to establish and maintain register of exempted nursing homes

subsection.content: The Director must, for the purposes of this Ordinance, establish and maintain a register of all scheduled nursing homes with a valid exemption.
A register under subsection (1) may be kept in a form, and may contain the information, that the Director considers appropriate.
The purpose of the register is to enable a member of the public to ascertain whether a home is operating with a valid exemption.

subsection.leadIn: The register must be made available for public inspection free of charge—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: through the Internet; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the office of the Director, or any other Government offices as the Director may direct, during normal office hours.

section.name: s133
section.heading: Power of entry into exempted nursing homes without warrant
section.leadIn: The Director or an authorized officer may, without a warrant issued by a magistrate, enter a scheduled nursing home for which an exemption is valid at any reasonable time and exercise a power specified in section 116 for ascertaining—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether this Ordinance and any condition of the exemption has been, and is being, complied with; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the safety, legality, quality and appropriateness of the services provided in the home.

subsection.content: This Division expires on a day to be appointed by the Secretary by notice published in the Gazette.
The day to be appointed by the Secretary must be at least 1 year after the day on which the notice is published.

division.name: D4
division.heading: Application for Day Procedure Centre Licence or Clinic Licence during Specified Period

section.name: s135
section.heading: Application for licence where day procedure centre already in operation

subsection.leadIn: This section applies in relation to a person’s application for a day procedure centre licence made under section 13 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person operates a day procedure centre (existing day procedure centre) on the date specified by the Director under subsection (6)(a) on the premises for which the application is made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the application is made within the period specified by the Director under subsection (6)(b).

subsection.leadIn: On receiving the application, the Director must issue a provisional day procedure centre licence permitting the applicant to operate the existing day procedure centre on the premises if the Director is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant is a fit and proper person to operate or exercise control over the centre;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person is to be appointed as the chief medical executive for the centre as required under section 49 and the person is a fit and proper person to administer the centre; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the operation of the centre by the applicant would not be contrary to the public interest.

subsection.leadIn: The Director must, on the basis of the operation of the existing day procedure centre, specify in the provisional day procedure centre licence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the practice that may be carried on in the centre;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the class of specialized service that may be provided in the centre; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the scale and scope of the services that may be provided in the centre.

subsection.content: A provisional day procedure centre licence may be issued subject to the conditions that the Director considers appropriate.

Despite section 25(2)(c), if the applicant is, at the time of the application, registered under the Hospitals, Nursing Homes and Maternity Homes Registration Ordinance (Cap. 165) or the Medical Clinics Ordinance (Cap. 343) for the premises, the application needs only to be accompanied by the fee specified in item 13 of Schedule 4.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date referred to in subsection (1)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a period within which an application for a day procedure centre licence under section 13 may be made in reliance on this section.

tr.td: 30 November 2018—see Cap. 633 sub. leg. A.
Beginning on 2 January 2020 and ending on 30 April 2020—see Cap. 633 sub. leg. F.

section.name: s136
section.heading: Application for licence where clinic already in operation

subsection.leadIn: This section applies in relation to a person’s application for a clinic licence made under section 13 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person operates a clinic (existing clinic) on the date specified by the Director under subsection (6)(a) on the premises for which the application is made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the application is made within the period specified by the Director under subsection (6)(b).

subsection.leadIn: On receiving the application, the Director must issue a provisional clinic licence permitting the applicant to operate the existing clinic on the premises if the Director is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant is a fit and proper person to operate or exercise control over the clinic;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person is to be appointed as the chief medical executive for the clinic as required under section 49 and the person is a fit and proper person to administer the clinic; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the operation of the clinic by the applicant would not be contrary to the public interest.

subsection.leadIn: The Director must, on the basis of the operation of the existing clinic, specify in the provisional clinic licence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the practice that may be carried on in the clinic; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the scale and scope of the services that may be provided in the clinic.

subsection.content: A provisional clinic licence may be issued subject to the conditions that the Director considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: Despite section 25(2)(c), if the applicant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: holds, at the time of the application, a valid hospital licence in relation to which section 127 applies and the premises are covered in the licence as associated premises; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is, at the time of the application, registered under the Medical Clinics Ordinance (Cap. 343) for the premises,

subsection.continued: the application needs only to be accompanied by the fee specified in item 14 of Schedule 4.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date referred to in subsection (1)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a period within which an application for a clinic licence under section 13 may be made in reliance on this section.

subsection.leadIn: A provisional licence issued under section 135(2) or 136(2) in relation to premises is valid for the period beginning on the date specified by the Director in the provisional licence and ending on the earlier of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the day a specified event occurs in relation to the premises; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Secretary has appointed a day under section 139 for the expiry of this Division—that day.

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (1)(a), each of the following is a specified event—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the issue of a licence under section 17 to the licensee of the provisional licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the refusal to issue a licence under section 17 to the licensee of the provisional licence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the application for a licence made under section 13 is withdrawn, or deemed to be withdrawn, by the licensee of the provisional licence.

tr.td: This section came into operation on 2 January 2020 (in so far as it relates to a provisional day procedure centre licence)—see L.N. 85 of 2019.
This section came into operation on 13 October 2025 (in so far as it relates to a provisional clinic licence)—see L.N. 110 of 2025.

section.name: s138
section.heading: Shared entrance acceptable in some cases

subsection.leadIn: This section applies in relation to a clinic if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a provisional clinic licence is issued for the clinic under section 136(2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: on the date the licence is issued—

subparagraph.content: the clinic has a private entrance that is shared with premises (shared entrance) that serve a purpose that is not reasonably incidental to the clinic (other premises); and
to access the clinic, it is necessary to pass from the shared entrance through part of the other premises (passage area).

subsection.leadIn: Section 67 does not apply in relation to the clinic during the validity period of the provisional clinic licence while—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the other premises are also managed or controlled by the licensee of the clinic;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any notice or sign of the clinic is displayed only at, or in the immediate vicinity of, the direct entrance to the clinic;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the passage area is not designated for a purpose other than passage or waiting (for example, it is not designated as a changing room);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: there is nothing in the passage area that blocks access to the clinic; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: access to the other premises does not involve passing through the clinic.

subsection.content: Subsection (2) does not limit any conditions to which the provisional clinic licence may be subject under section 136(4).
The licensee must ensure that access to the clinic through the passage area is granted to the Director or an authorized officer for the purposes of section 113.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: private entrance (私人入口) means an entrance to premises that do not consist of any common area of the building in which the premises are situated.

subsection.content: This Division expires on a day to be appointed by the Secretary by notice published in the Gazette.
The day to be appointed by the Secretary must be at least 1 year after the day on which the notice is published.
